comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
So, who has identified and dated this photo ?

Why does this ship have an extensive superstructure which looks entirely different to the two other, authentic, photos of the french corvette Dupleix, which was notable in the Japanese upheavals around 1868 ?

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
This is not the French corvette Dupleix at all.

It is not a warship.   Note the extensive wooden superstructure.  It is completely different to the photographs of the warship Dupleix.

There have been at least 4 commercial ships called Dupleix.  If the ship depicted in this photo is called Dupleix,   then it is probably the steamship Dupleix, of 1400 tons,  which operated between  Sydney and Noumea regularly between 1883 and 1888,   at which time it was advertised for sale by its owners, the compagnie des messageries maritimes,  in Sydney.[ SMH 21 April 1888].

Another ship called Dupleix also operated between Sydney and Noumea in the mid 1920's, it might even be that one.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: And furthermore,  the Herald of 2 March 1889  reports refurbishment and re-boilering of the well known ship Dupleix at Mort's Dock,  for a new steamship service to New Zealand ports.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: This ship was re-named Jubilee in August 1889

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
And was proposed to be renamed Klondyke in 1898,  although it is unclear if this ever happened.

After 4 years on the New Zealand run, and several incidents,  the Jubilee was laid up in 1893 at Snail's bay, offered for sale in 1896,  and aparently unused between 1893 and 1898.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: The caption on this photo should be changed,  because gullible morons have been linking it the french warship on both the english and french wikipedia.

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: The photograph was probably just titled "Dupleix" on the reverse, and, in the days before online services, it could be difficult to research ships in books, because as you point out, there are often many ships with the same name. The State Library is an enormous library and cataloguers just don't have the time to fully reasearch each image. We know at least that it is probably not the 1920's ship because of the large format albumen print which is the type of photograph here. This type of photograph was generally being phased out by the 1920's.
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Yes I know, its not your fault,  it may well have been mis-identified by the person who donated the photo in 1953, from the name possibly related to the former manager of the dockyard.  It certainly was harder before the Internet.

comment.author: 55373366@N02
comment._content: Excellent identification and corrective research! Thank you. It may have takern a little longer to sort these things out  pre-Internet, but at least the researched and written hard copies in libraries weren't so prone to the sort of online chinese whispers, whereby a misidentification or error becomes established fact regardless of historical reality.
